instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> / <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> compatible?
threads.message:
So bit of an odd question going on in the workshop, sorry if this sort of question is not allowed

We have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and we haven't really worked on them much, but we have noticed the USB-C port controllers are CD3217s instead of CD3215s - Are there's actually compatible so if I had a bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> can I put a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> on instead? Have searched the forum but found nothing about this - currently going through whatever data sheets that are available on these two ICs to see if there are any noticeable differences but can't seem to see anything jump out about them.

threads.title: <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> / <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> compatible?
threads.message:
Looks to have totally different layout.

[MEDIA=youtube]ZHwI2LAUAD8[/MEDIA]

threads.title: <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> / <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> compatible?
threads.message: Ahh that's interesting - Apple making it even more annoying to use parts from different boards, was hoping to use a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> instead but never mind. Thank you for that video!
